rev.comment: This image use does not comply with [[WP:NFCC]] #10c and MUST be removed until it does. Thank you.
rev.diff:
Line 2: Line 2:
In [[baseball]], an '''extra base hit''' ('''EB''', '''EBH''' or '''XBH'''), also known as a '''long hit''', is any [[hit (baseball)|base hit]] on which the [[batting (baseball)|batter]] is able to advance past first base without the benefit of a fielder either committing an [[error (baseball)|error]] or opting to make a throw to retire another [[baserunning|base runner]] (see [[fielder's choice]]). Extra base hits are often not listed separately in tables of [[baseball statistics]], but are easily determined by calculating the sum total of a batter's [[double (baseball)|double]]s, [[triple (baseball)|triple]]s, and [[home run]]s.
In [[baseball]], an '''extra base hit''' ('''EB''', '''EBH''' or '''XBH'''), also known as a '''long hit''', is any [[hit (baseball)|base hit]] on which the [[batting (baseball)|batter]] is able to advance past first base without the benefit of a fielder either committing an [[error (baseball)|error]] or opting to make a throw to retire another [[baserunning|base runner]] (see [[fielder's choice]]). Extra base hits are often not listed separately in tables of [[baseball statistics]], but are easily determined by calculating the sum total of a batter's [[double (baseball)|double]]s, [[triple (baseball)|triple]]s, and [[home run]]s.
â
[[File:Lou-boudreau.jpg |180px|upright=3.| thumb|Hall of Famer [[Lou Boudreau]]]]
 
The record for most extra-base hits by one batter, in one game, is five, held by several different players, including [[Joe Adcock]] and [[Lou Boudreau]]. The record for most career extra-base hits is 1,477, held by [[Hank Aaron]].
The record for most extra-base hits by one batter, in one game, is five, held by several different players, including [[Joe Adcock]] and [[Lou Boudreau]]. The record for most career extra-base hits is 1,477, held by [[Hank Aaron]].
